case_vignette: A 5-year-old female presents with a plaque on her left leg. The lesion appeared a few months after her birth. It has been increasing in size proportionally to her growth. The parents mentions that the skin lesion sometimes becomes irritated, erythematous and itchy when the patient plays with it or when she gets sick. Physical exam reveals a red-brown well delimited plaque on her left leg without any noticeable erythema or epidermal changes.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have this mark on my left leg that's been growing as I get bigger, and sometimes it gets red, irritated, and itchy, especially when I touch it a lot or when I'm not feeling well.
How long have you had this mark on your leg?
I've had the mark since I was a baby, a few months after I was born.
Does the mark change in color or bleed?
No, it doesn't change color or bleed.
Have you noticed any changes in the texture or raised areas on the mark?
No, there are no changes in texture or raised areas on the mark.
Do you have any other similar marks or lesions elsewhere on your body?
No, I don't have any other marks like this one on my body.
Do you have any known allergies?
The case vignette does not provide information regarding allergies.
Has anyone in your family had similar skin marks or a history of skin conditions?
The case vignette does not provide information regarding family history of similar skin marks or skin conditions.
Is the mark's growth proportional to your overall growth?
Yes, the mark has been growing in size as I grow.
Final Diagnosis: Congenital melanocytic nevus.
